content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’ve been having a lot of trouble sleeping lately. It’s been tough to shut my brain off at night because I keep thinking about work and all the stress that comes with it. My partner suggested I talk to someone, so here I am. Honestly, I’m not sure how much this will help, but I do know I can’t go on like this forever.

Thank you for being open about what you’re experiencing—it sounds like the stress at work and difficulty shutting off those thoughts have been weighing heavily on you. It's understandable that this has been tough, and it's important that you're here exploring ways to deal with it. What do you think has been making work so stressful?

I think the main thing is that I'm worried about getting fired since the company is struggling, and I feel like I’m not performing as well as I should. I keep thinking about how losing my job would impact my family—paying bills, setting a good example for my kids, all of that weighs on me. It's just hard to shake those thoughts, especially at night when it's quiet and everything feels amplified.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of responsibility and concern for your family, and those worries about your job have made it even harder to relax when you need rest the most. You really care about being there for your family, and it shows in how deeply this is affecting you. How do you normally try to manage these overwhelming thoughts when they come up?

Most nights, I end up grabbing my phone and scrolling through social media or watching videos. It distracts me for a while, but deep down I know it just makes things worse because it keeps my mind racing about other stuff. I’ve tried putting it down, but I always seem to go back to it.

It’s understandable—turning to your phone might feel like a quick escape when the racing thoughts become overwhelming. At the same time, it sounds like you’re noticing that it’s not really helping in the long run, and it might even be adding to the challenge of calming your mind. What do you imagine could help you break that cycle when those restless nights hit?

I’m honestly not sure. I’ve thought about things like trying to read before bed or maybe some sort of relaxation technique, but it’s hard to even know where to start. And when I’m in the middle of feeling that way, it doesn’t feel easy to change what I’m doing.

It takes a lot of thought and effort to even start considering alternatives, especially when it feels easier to stick with what's familiar during those tough moments. Thinking about reading or relaxation techniques is a step toward exploring what might help, even if it doesn't feel easy to implement right now. What do you think has kept you from trying some of those ideas so far?

I guess it feels like nothing will work well enough to quiet my thoughts, so I don’t even start. Plus, when I’m that stressed, it’s easier to just default to grabbing my phone because it’s such a habit. Maybe I’m afraid I’ll fail at trying something different, so I avoid it altogether.

It's really brave to acknowledge those fears of trying something new, especially when you're feeling so stressed. Habits can be comforting in the moment, even if they aren’t helping in the way you’d like. It sounds like you care deeply about getting better sleep and breaking free from this cycle, even though taking that first step feels uncertain. What do you think might help you feel more confident in giving one of those changes a try?

Maybe if I start with something small, like setting my phone aside for just ten minutes before bed, it could feel less overwhelming. Or maybe having someone hold me accountable, like my partner, could help me stick to it. I feel like I need some sort of structure or push to actually follow through.

Starting small with something manageable, like a brief time away from your phone, sounds like a thoughtful way to ease into change without feeling overwhelmed. Having your partner involved as support or accountability could give you encouragement and a sense of shared effort. It shows you're already thinking of ways to make it doable. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about before exploring how this plan might fit into your routine?

I think I’m okay for now. Thank you for listening and helping me sort through this—it’s given me a bit of clarity. I’ll try to take it one step at a time with those smaller changes and see where it goes. Thanks again.
